text: Interesting - cheers for the insight

Has anyone had problems with overheating hard drives?

I have a Samsung Evo 970 plus NVME. And 3950X cpu. I'm using it to backtest with Flumine on 32 cores.

So when that happens, my machine is looping through 32 files at the same time. And the NVME gets to over 70C.

I'm wondering if it could be better to load the full files to RAM, and then iterate over them from RAM. This will obviously use more RAM, but the files are smaller anyway. Perhaps the user could specify which method they want to use?

What do you think <@U4H19D1D2>?

This is the bit that I'm thinking of refactoring: <https://github.com/liampauling/betfair/blob/10b268673923dcfaf3847b28ddcd963f775661c5/betfairlightweight/streaming/betfairstream.py#L331-L356>

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

Has anyone had problems with overheating hard drives?

I have a Samsung Evo 970 plus NVME. And 3950X cpu. I'm using it to backtest with Flumine on 32 cores.

So when that happens, my machine is looping through 32 files at the same time. And the NVME gets to over 70C.

I'm wondering if it could be better to load the full files to RAM, and then iterate over them from RAM. This will obviously use more RAM, but the files are smaller anyway. Perhaps the user could specify which method they want to use?

text: What's the danger level?

The data sheet says the operating range goes up to 70C. Using the `sensors` command, it says the critical level is 84.8C. Given we are now in winter, ambient temperatures in my room could easily get over 10C hotter in the summer months. But I do not know if that will translate to 10C+ hotter temperatures on the SSD.

text: After some investigating, I'd dispute that it's not a frequent thing - AFAICT it happens to every horse in every race. They publish an RPR before the race and then afterwards change to an RPR that corresponds to how well the horse did in that race. I've attached an example card as it appeared pre race. Now take a look at the RPR values on the results page here: <https://www.racingpost.com/results/394/southwell-aw/2021-01-19/774604>

attachments.text: As a quantitative analyst at Smartodds, you’ll be part of an exciting environment, predicting outcomes of professional sports on behalf of our clients. text: Modelling the actual sports
fundamental pricing I believe

*So you’re conflating two numbers here. Pre race what you are seeing is a projected RPR that the horse will run too. This is is a projection generated pre-race by the in house handicappers for the Racing Post. As you say these numbers are no longer accessible after a race has been run.* 

*What you see post race is a performance metric for the ability the horse showed on the day. This is set by the handicappers taking into account a number of factors including the weight carried by the horse, distance beaten/ahead of the other horses in the race any trouble in running etc. This number is generally set but is also the one I was warning about potentially being adjusted according to subsequent information (e.g. the race turning out to be a strong form race).*

elements.text: So you’re conflating two numbers here. Pre race what you are seeing is a projected RPR that the horse will run too. This is is a projection generated pre-race by the in house handicappers for the Racing Post. As you say these numbers are no longer accessible after a race has been run.

What you see post race is a performance metric for the ability the horse showed on the day. This is set by the handicappers taking into account a number of factors including the weight carried by the horse, distance beaten/ahead of the other horses in the race any trouble in running etc. This number is generally set but is also the one I was warning about potentially being adjusted according to subsequent information (e.g. the race turning out to be a strong form race).
